Table 1. Number and rate of violent victimizations, by type of crime, 2018–2022
Report title: Criminal Victimization, 2022   NCJ 307089
Data source: Bureau of Justice Statistics, National Crime Victimization Survey, 2018–2022
Authors: Alexandra Thompson and Susannah N. Tapp, PhD, BJS Statisticians
Refer questions to: askbjs@usdoj.gov 202-307-0765
Date of version: 9/14/2023
Table 1. Number and rate of violent victimizations, by type of crime, 2018–2022
Type of violent crime
Total violent crime/b
Violent crime excluding simple assault/d
Selected characteristics of violent crime/e
Note: Details may not sum to totals due to rounding. Includes threatened, attempted, and completed occurrences of crimes. See appendix table 2 for standard errors.
*Comparison year.
†Difference with comparison year is significant at the 95% confidence level.
‡Difference with comparison year is significant at the 90% confidence level.
a/Rate is per 1,000 persons age 12 or older. See appendix table 19 for person populations.
b/Excludes homicide because the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) is based on interviews with victims.
c/See Methodology for details on the measurement of rape or sexual assault in the NCVS.
d/Includes rape or sexual assault, robbery, and aggravated assault.
e/Violent crime categories such as domestic violence and violent crime with an injury are not mutually exclusive from other violent crime categories or other selected characteristics.
f/Includes the subset of violent victimizations that were committed by current or former intimate partners or family members.
g/Includes the subset of violent victimizations that were committed by current or former spouses, boyfriends, or girlfriends.
Source: Bureau of Justice Statistics, National Crime Victimization Survey, 2018–2022.
